GraphLib package¶

Submodules¶

GraphLib.DirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: object

The class that implements a directed Graph.

It’s also the base class of all other Graphs.

Parameters:name – a graph optionnaly has a name. It is only used by GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.toDot().
addArc(origin, target)¶

Add an arc to the Graph. If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(v)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

Returns:the list of vertices directly accessible from v
getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Get the succession of vertices on the path from vertex start to vertex end. Paths are stored in previous.

Parameters:
  • start – the starting point of the path.
  • end – the ending point of the path.
  • previous – a way to store paths. It should be obtained by a search in the graph such as GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.runBreadthFirst() before this method is called. see below for more information of this structure
Returns:

a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

Structure of the previous parameter :

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices. These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous previous is constructed as follows :

  • Each vertex k accessible from start is a key in the dictionnary.

  • The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k on the path from start to k

    Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

Returns:the list of vertices that give direct access to v
printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start, following the Breadth First Search algorithm.

Returns:previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. See GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.getPath() for a good description of this dictionary and its usage.
toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

GraphLib.UndirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.UndirectedGraph.UndirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph

The class that implements an undirected Graph.

It is basically a directed Graph with symetrical arcs.

addArc(origin, target)¶

Add an undirected arc to the Graph. If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(v)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

Returns:the list of vertices directly accessible from v
getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Get the succession of vertices on the path from vertex start to vertex end. Paths are stored in previous.

Parameters:
  • start – the starting point of the path.
  • end – the ending point of the path.
  • previous – a way to store paths. It should be obtained by a search in the graph such as GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.runBreadthFirst() before this method is called. see below for more information of this structure
Returns:

a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

Structure of the previous parameter :

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices. These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous previous is constructed as follows :

  • Each vertex k accessible from start is a key in the dictionnary.

  • The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k on the path from start to k

    Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

Returns:the list of vertices that give direct access to v
printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start, following the Breadth First Search algorithm.

Returns:previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. See GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.getPath() for a good description of this dictionary and its usage.
toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

GraphLib.WeightedDirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.WeightedDirectedGraph.WeightedDirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph

The class that implements an weighted directed Graph.

It is basically a directed Graph where arcs have weights

addArc(origin, target, weight=1.0)¶

Add a weighted arc to the Graph.

If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(v)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

getArcWeight(origin, target)¶

get the weight of an arc in the graph

If the arc does not belong to the graph, a key Exception is raised

getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

Returns:the list of vertices directly accessible from v
getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Get the succession of vertices on the path from vertex start to vertex end. Paths are stored in previous.

Parameters:
  • start – the starting point of the path.
  • end – the ending point of the path.
  • previous – a way to store paths. It should be obtained by a search in the graph such as GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.runBreadthFirst() before this method is called. see below for more information of this structure
Returns:

a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

Structure of the previous parameter :

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices. These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous previous is constructed as follows :

  • Each vertex k accessible from start is a key in the dictionnary.

  • The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k on the path from start to k

    Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

Returns:the list of vertices that give direct access to v
printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start, following the Breadth First Search algorithm.

Returns:previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. See GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.getPath() for a good description of this dictionary and its usage.
runDijkstra(start)¶

The Diskstra Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start and compute the smallest path to all of them, taking the weights of arcs into account.

Parameters:start – the starting vertex of the search.
Returns:previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. See GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.getPath() for a good description of this dictionary and its usage.

Warning

The search for a current vertex to explore is not at all optimal in the current implementation. A priority queue should be used instead.

toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

GraphLib.WeightedUndirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.WeightedUndirectedGraph.WeightedUndirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: GraphLib.UndirectedGraph.UndirectedGraph

The class that implements an weighted undirected Graph.

It is basically an undirected Graph where arcs have weights A graph can have a name, only is used in the .dot output

addArc(origin, target, weight=1.0)¶

Add a weighted arc to the Graph.

If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(v)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

getArcWeight(origin, target)¶

get the weight of an arc in the graph

If the arc does not belong to the graph, a key Exception is raised

a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

Returns:the list of vertices that give direct access to v

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start, following the Breadth First Search algorithm.

Returns:previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. See GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph.getPath() for a good description of this dictionary and its usage.
runDijkstra(start)¶

The Diskstra Algorithm :

Information about this function can be found there : GraphLib.WeightedDirectedGraph.WeightedDirectedGraph.runDijkstra() It is the one that is really called…

toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.
